@vahidhashemian Please take some time to review this minor PR. Thanks.

In the original gradle thread, a number of issues were raised if the same output directory is used by Eclipse and Gradle:

https://discuss.gradle.org/t/eclipse-generated-files-should-be-put-in-the-same-place-as-the-gradle-generated-files/6986/2

It may be worth adding a gradle property to allow people to choose the behaviour. Regarding the default, it would seem that the safe option should be the default (`bin` is clearly not a good default though).
Seems like the same system test failed again.

http://confluent-kafka-branch-builder-system-test-results.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/2017-01-23--001.1485174678--dguy--system-tests--7516532/report.html

The issue with 0.10.1.0 failing to start up appears to be https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-4688 .  Let's just remove that version from the tested list until KAFKA-4688 can be committed and our environments are updated.

Test FAILed (JDK 7 and Scala 2.10).

@rajinisivaram - i've changed the tests to use the non-strict mode, like actual code.

note that the scenario you've described of constantly muting and unmuting is also possible with a non strict pool:

1. server has N incoming connections
2. at every iteration pool only has enough memory to accommodate a single request
3. at every call to poll, N connections are unmuted, 1 is services, N-1 are muted again, progress indication is set to true
4. next iteration either makes no further progress (in which case the next after that will actually wait for a while), or again repeats this.

this isn't as tight a loop as with a strict pool (as the 2nd invocation will not have memory and will not make progress), but its still sub-optimal.

a more optimal solution would be to somehow remember the smallest unfulfilled request, have some pool.canAllocate(long bytes) - which will account for strict vs non-struct - and only unmute is the result is true. since there's one pool and multiple selectors this isn't guaranteed to not unmute for nothing.

to me this is a corner case though, as under these conditions currently the broker just explodes. i can implement the canAllocate(bytes) API if you think its required, but I think this is optimizing a corner case.

I located the failing log message here from Kafka:

http://confluent-kafka-branch-builder-system-test-results.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/2017-01-21--001.1485018206--cmccabe--KAFKA-4548--6d2094c/TestProducerConsumerCompat/test_produce_consume/broker_version%3D0.10.1.0/4.tgz

It is a single line:
```
bash: /opt/kafka-0.10.1.0/bin/kafka-server-start.sh: No such file or directory
```

So this confirms that the problem is the test environment, not the test.
I think we also need to update vagrantfile. I'll take a look when I get home.
@cmccabe https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/trunk/vagrant/base.sh#L64-L69 is where we install it for Vagrant VMs.
And I should mention that I made sure the corresponding URLs will be there -- in that case we haven't been relying on random mirrors and just used a reliable source of our own.
